contentrichtext.text: [[File:HETE 2.jpg|thumb|High Energy Transient Explorer.]] The '''High Energy Transient Explorer''' (abbreviated '''HETE'''; also known as '''Explorer 79''') was an [[United States|American]] astronomical satellite with international participation (mainly Japan and France). The prime objective of HETE was to carry out the first multiwavelength study of [[gamma-ray burst]]s with [[ultraviolet|UV]], [[X-ray]], and [[gamma-ray]] instruments mounted on a single, compact spacecraft. A unique feature of the HETE mission was its capability to localize GRBs with ~10 [[arc second]] accuracy in near real time aboard the spacecraft, and to transmit these positions directly to a network of receivers at existing ground-based observatories enabling rapid, sensitive follow-up studies in the [[radio]], [[infrared|IR]], and [[visible light|optical]] bands. The satellite bus for the first HETE was designed and built by AeroAstro, Inc. of Herndon, VA; the replacement satellite, '''HETE-2''', was built by MIT based on the original HETE design. ==Launch attempts== The first HETE was lost during the launch on Nov.4, 1996. The [[Pegasus rocket]] achieved a good orbit, but explosive bolts releasing HETE from another satellite (Argentina's SAC-B) and from its DPAF envelope failed to charge, dooming both satellites. A battery on the third stage of the rocket and responsible for these bolts cracked during the ascent. A second HETE satellite, HETE-2, was launched on October 9, 2000 in a follow-up mission. It was similar to the first HETE, but replaced the UV camera with an additional X-ray camera (Soft X-ray Camera or SXC) capable of higher localization accuracy than the original X-ray instrument (Wide-Field X-ray Monitor or WXM). HETE-2 was placed in a 625 km altitude earth orbit with an inclination of 0-2 degrees.<ref name=HETE-sc>[http://space.mit.edu/HETE/spacecraft.html HETE-2 Spacecraft]</ref> ==Achievements== Among the achievements of the HETE-2 mission are: # The discovery of [[GRB 030329]], a widely observed, nearby gamma ray burst, firmly connecting GRBs with supernovas. # The discovery of [[GRB 050709]], which was the first short/hard GRB to be found with an optical counterpart, leading to a firm establishment of the cosmological origin of this subclass of GRBs. # Dark bursts, or GRBs previously thought to have no optical counterparts, are not completely optically dark. Some of these dark GRBs fade in the optical very rapidly, others are dimmer but detectable with large (meter class) telescopes. # The establishment of another subclass of GRBs, the less energetic [[List of astronomy acronyms|X-Ray Flashes]] (XRF), and its first optical counterpart. # The first to send out arcminute positions of GRBs to the observation community within tens of seconds of the onset of GRB (and in a few instances, while the burst was ongoing). ==Burst alert summary== The HETE website <ref>[http://space.mit.edu/HETE/Bursts/ HETE Bursts]</ref> lists 6 in 2001, 19 in 2002, 25 in 2003, 19 in 2004, 12 in 2005, 3 in 2006 - the last reported being in March 2006. The trigger summaries<ref>[http://space.mit.edu/HETE/Bursts/H40xx.html HETE Trigger Summaries: H40xx (from 15 Jan 2006)]</ref> lists 2 GRBs in May 2006 and an XRB in Jan 2007. ==Latest status== As of March 2007 "The operational efficiency of the HETE spacecraft and instruments has decreased due to the advanced age of the NiCd batteries on board."<ref>[http://space.mit.edu/HETE/mission_status.html HETE Mission Status]</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://space.mit.edu/HETE/ HETE-2] at MIT {{Space observatories}} {{Explorer program}} {{Orbital launches in 1996}} [[Category:Gamma-ray telescopes]] [[Category:X-ray telescopes]] [[Category:Space telescopes]] [[Category:Artificial satellites orbiting Earth]] [[Category:1996 in spaceflight]]
